stem: An 18-month-old child is brought to the ED by a frantic parent. Based on the documentation in the Pediatric Toxicology & Observation Log, what is the nurse's highest priority action?

tabs.title: SBAR Situation
tabs.content:
Situation: Accidental ingestion of grandparent's medication.
Background: Parent found child playing with an open bottle of Methadone 10mg tablets 1 hour ago. Bottle was previously full.
Assessment: Child is very difficult to arouse. Pupils are 1mm (Pinpoint). RR is 8 and shallow.

tabs.title: Vital Signs Trends
tabs.content:
IndicatorArrival (10 mins ago)Current
Heart Rate11084 (Bradycardia starting)
Resp Rate148 (Dropping)
SpO294%88% (on room air)

tabs.title: Methadone Reference
tabs.content:
Drug Type: Long-acting synthetic opioid.
Half-life: 24-36 hours.
Pediatric Danger: 1 pill can be lethal to a toddler.

options.text: Administer IV Naloxone (Narcan) and prepare for repeated doses
Administer syrup of Ipecac to induce vomiting
Prepare for discharge once the child is awake and alert

rationale.correct: The child is experiencing life-threatening opioid toxicity (Methodone). **IV Naloxone (a1)** is the highest priority to restore the respiratory drive. Because Methadone is a very long-acting opioid (Half-life 24-36 hours), the single dose of Narcan (Short-acting) will wear off, and the child will stop breathing again. Repeated doses or a continuous Narcan infusion will be mandatory for the next 24-48 hours.
clinicalPearls: Methadone: 'One pill can kill' a child.
Pinpoint pupils + Respiratory depression = Opioids until proven otherwise.
Ipecac (a3) is NEVER recommended anymore as it increases the risk of aspiration.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing Gastric Lavage (a2) as the priority.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the patient is not breathing (RR 8, SpO2 88%), you fix the BREATHING (Airway/Antidote) first. Lavage is secondary and carries high risk in a somnolent patient.

mnemonic.title: Tiny Toxic
mnemonic.expansion: One pill. Long chill (Methadone duration). Give the Narcan until they're drill (alert).
